titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Averill A. Liebow Collection
titlestmt.author: Finding aid by Todd A. Lane and Toby A. Appel

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 02:00

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

did.abstract: Averill A. Liebow, professor of pathology at Yale School of Medicine, was a member of the Joint Commission for the Investigation of the Effects of the Atomic Bomb in Japan organized by Col. Ashley W. Oughterson, on leave from Yale. Liebow spent four months in Hiroshima beginning in October 1945 and kept a diary. The collection contains photographs and documents from an exhibit on the Joint Commission and the medical effects of the bomb in Hiroshima that was prepared for the Medical Library in 1965 and then loaned for display in Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1966.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Averill A. Liebow to the Medical Historical Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Yale University does not own copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Averill A. Liebow Collection, Historical Library, Cushing/Whitney Medical Library, Yale University, New Haven, CT

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Folders and envelopes of photographs from a previous arrangement have been integrated into a single sequence of folders.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: A native of Austria, Averill Liebow came to the United States as a young boy. He graduated magnum cum laude from City College of New York, and received his medical degree from Yale University in 1935. Appointed an assistant in pathology at Yale in 1935, he rose through the ranks to full professor in 1951. In 1968 he accepted the chairmanship of the department of pathology at the University of California, San Diego, which he held until his retirement in 1975. While on active duty during World War II, Liebow served as a pathologist with the 39th General Hospital, the Yale Unit in the South Pacific. During this time, he compiled elegant studies of cutaneous diphtheria that made specific treatment possible for a form of "jungle rot," which was a major problem in the South Pacific theater of the war. Immediately after the war, Liebow was recruited as a member of the Joint Commission for the Investigation of the Effects of the Atomic Bomb in Japan organized by Col. Ashley W. Oughterson, on leave from Yale, and Prof. Masao Tsuzuki of Japan. Liebow and the members of the Commission reached Hiroshima on October 12. During the four months Liebow remained in Hiroshima, he wrote an extensive diary in shorthand of his observations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection relates to the pathological studies in Hiroshima after the bombing conducted by Liebow and his colleague on the Joint Commission for the Investigation of the Effects of the Atomic Bomb. The main portion consists of the materials from a 1965 exhibit at Yale University which was then sent for exhibit in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan in 1966.. It included portions of Liebow's original shorthand diary, correspondence, and reproductions of original photographs, charts and graphs. These document the damage to buildings, casualties, the flash burns and other injuries suffered by individuals, a case report, and other work of the Joint Committee. Much, but not all, of this material was published in "Encounter with Disaster: A Medical Diary of Hiroshima 1945," Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine, 38(2) (October 1965). The exhibit materials have been numbered by Madeline Stanton in Roman numerals by "case" and then with Arabic numerals (I.1, I.2, etc.). The collection also contains other items by Liebow among them, shorthand notes, typescripts, and another case report. Finally, the collection includes various typescripts and reprints related to the medical studies.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in three series: 1. The exhibit. 2. Additional Liebow materials. 3. Other writings and reprints.

odd.head: Appendix: Exhibit Case Contents
odd.p: See case labels for more information.

controlaccess.corpname: United States. Joint Commission for the Investigation of the Effects of the Atomic Bomb in Japan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The exhibit was shown at Yale in 1965 and then sent by Madeline Stanton, Librarian of the Historical Collections, Yale Medical Library, to George B. Darling, Director of the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission in 1966 for exhibit in ten panels in Nagasaki and Hiroshima. The paper labels, typed in New Haven, were keyed to the documents and photographs by Stanton using a Roman numeral for each case.

did.unittitle: Publicity and correspondence concerning publication and exhibits

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publicity on the publication of Encounter with Disaster, correspondence between Madeline Stanton, Librarian of Historical Collections, Yale Medical Library, and George B. Darling, Director of the Atomic Bomb Casuaty Commission on the lending of exhibit materials to be shown in Nagasaki and Hiroshima; and list of Japanese contacts.

did.unittitle: Averill A. Liebow, Encounter with Disaster: A Medical Diary of Hiroshima, 1945

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Published as an issue of Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine 38(2) Oct. 1965. Many of the photographs in the exhibit are in this publication.

Miyaki to Liebow, n.d., Luther Terry, USPHS, Tokyo, to Dr. Oughterson or Col. Mason, 1945 November 23; Receipt for the first consignment of records and photographs of the Joint Commission, 1945 November 25.
